and so um that got us to wanting to explore what else could we do with video
and messaging or or video with social people um and led to another project that we
called experiences to go this is originally called um uh
grandma on a box because uh that's what the telepresence robot that michael referred to is usually called john in
the box but people didn't like the way grammar on the box sounded so then we call it grandma to go which then broaden because we only had a
few grandmothers that use this but anyway this was an attempt to take video
conferencing out of the home and into the places where kids activities occur
because a lot of these was driven of course by attending kids activities that might be
sporting events outdoors it might be birthday parties and special venues
and frankly one of the critiques about skype is that often a skype call your sort of
canonical weekly call with uh uncle joe it often is in the same computer in the
same room week after week connecting those two rooms and not very much as interesting is happening
other than the talking faces so we wanted to try to take that out of the
that kind of those four walls and see well what could we do by enabling video conferencing out in the wild
so that led to this rather science fair kind of project where we
cobbled together a camera that a camcorder that allowed
pan tilt and zoom importantly because a lot of these kids events are kind of farther away
and could also deal with lighting we wanted it to be portable it's not beautifully portable but you can throw
it in a car or take it someplace and we used skype because that was a
tool that reached a lot of people didn't have to do any customized install on the remote side
and we used a 4g hotspot that allowed it to go virtually anywhere
especially in the puget sound area or silicon valley area where this work was done so this was this portable
video terminal and it had this affordance that there was a tablet there that showed the remote person so unlike
when you record something for a camcorder and you don't see the audience here we wanted to give the audience a
sense of presence a sense of being able to come up and interact with that person
and so again we recruited people to take this out and do what they wanted
with and we captured lots of diverse activity um fishing birthday parties play centers
and a lot of these were interestingly though you might think this is kind of
targeted for remote people a lot of these were families where one partner or the other couldn't attend
because of scheduling constraints but wanted to be involved in in the event so
a case where the uh let's see i think in this case the husband's watching the swim team
practice and the wife wanted to join remotely so they're they live in the same city but scheduling wise it was they wanted
to try this out virtually and again just a quick sample of what
this looked like this was a fishing a birthday party held at a fish hatchery
and they were connecting with a grandmother till that time
they walk up to it and talk to the grandmother
and in one case the grandmother could see that they caught a fish and started kind of cheering or plotting even before
there was a conversation about it so it really felt like she could be involved in that interaction
so just some quotes about how people felt in this a feeling of being part of the activity
uh that they were sitting there right next to them to share in the activity with their kids uh like they were both
together and and that was exactly what we were going for is that video is
not just a medium for kind of projecting a talking head but it's a medium that allows remote people to be part of an
activity together and it actually led to a realization that there are many
stakeholders in these kinds of interactions right so obviously there's the remote person um
the proverbial grandmother that wants to be part of a kid's activity and then there's the local observer the sort of
person that is helping the grandmother attend and actually oftentimes there's an interesting social interaction
between those two because usually let's take the grandmother case usually it's the grandmother's own child son or
daughter that is you know doing all this and so while they're watching five-year-old
soccer which isn't actually a thrill a minute they would catch up on their social chit chat right they would have
the usual parent-child discussion as if they were sitting in the bleachers together
and the the kids activity was sort of an occasion to come together on that
so it was important to support that interaction as well as showing what's going on with the kids
and then there were the kids the local people taking part in activity who would from time to time want to come up and
say something directly to grandma and also would want to have the sense that not only the local people there but
remote people are attending as well so though they're an interesting part of the stakeholder
and the other stakeholder were the people around the audience okay so can we do this in a way that doesn't seem
strange or weird and this one in particular this was a high school track and field meet and
this is the one example where the high school daughter came up and said i don't want to look weird or something because
you're doing this thing and watching me and so so she was very aware of the social context of what it would look
like that this thing was sitting in the stands watching her the other thing that happened is that
because they were they were often local people we actually got a few conversations between the remote person
and other bystanders other people who are attending the event and we wanted to
think about how to afford for that and that's an interesting question you know think about this compared to say google
glass where the real person could be watching something but you have no awareness of what's going on it's a
little bit like the invisible headset uh people that you talk to and so this takes a different
approach by making that remote person more real or more visible

a summer intern and presented at interact in last year
and this was actually this had had some interesting parts about the methodology first we basically
did a survey do you ever try to watch tv or videos together with someone remotely
and while you're doing that have some connection like a skype call or maybe
just a phone call so that you feel like you're watching the program together
so the survey asks if people do that and if so how they're doing that um this again started with uh employees at our
company and then mushroomed beyond and we had just a number of basic questions about
tell us more about how you do this and your demographics an interesting part about the study is
that the survey responses came from
full-time employees and this happened during the summer so there are a lot of summer interns and there's obviously an age demographic difference
there and that shows up in how people kind of use this the next thing we did
which was interesting methodologically is just ask people who do this who watch
videos together the next time you do it
tell us about it through a survey and if you'd like to loop us in on a skype call so in other
words they're watching tv together they have a skype call going with each other and they make a skype call to one of our
basically um automatic bot skype bots that records the conversation for research purposes uh as and we get to
see what's going on in their homes in this case which is kind of an interesting thing from a research point of view because we as
researchers don't have to go visit all these homes personally they can just loop us in whenever they do it
uh whenever the time is convenient for them and we actually don't have to be there to capture that data
so it was scheduled on their own time the third part of the study was a lab study where we actually brought people
in tried a couple different configurations of doing this uh and i'll
just kind of quickly bruise through that one is you know when you're sitting side by side uh another
is that the remote person appears as a picture in a picture it's a really small
rectangle on the tv screen so you're watching the tv and you see the other person remotely and the third condition
was what we call the proxy condition where you know you have a screen or kind of a place dedicated for that remote
person and you're again watching together um and a quick example of what this looked
like to show um what what it feels like to kind of share those reactions while you're watching tv
together you know i'm sure you don't want to get caught up in anything that's illegal right

so but the one thing that was interesting for us is that um in the survey where we ask you know do
you do this or would you be interested a small percentage of people did try it
um and roughly equal percentage said they wanted to try it um but half of the
people said you know this basically sounds like too much trouble or like it wouldn't be satisfying and yet
in the field study or the lab study once we did give them the actual experience of trying this um
people said oh you know now that i see how i could do this i'd like to do this again it's just that it suggests that there is
this bit of a hump of getting people to actually experience it first and once they see that it is actually
possible with the infrastructure infrastructure that we have they would be generally more interested
in trying this again so that is uh another indicator of the
of just sort of getting over the the initial hump of well i never thought i could do that before um but we do have
a technology now that reaches into people's homes that that could enable this kind of work
the other interesting thing is that when you broke down by age obviously more people in the intern demographic were
doing and trying this than people that were older

if you're kind of video conferencing and so we've been leveraging that and other companies have commercially looked

so reflecting a little bit on this enterprise and consumer usage
what have we learned by kind of looking at these side by side first of all for me i think it's
interesting that as i said at the beginning the technology stack is essentially the
same and it's the social issues around it that are kind of driving these different uses so it's a
great illustration of a social technical system where uh it's the cul it's the connection the collaboration of both of
them that create these different use cases another thing and this is i think true
for both uh enterprise and consumer is it's not only for geographically remote
i mean you might think of video conferencing as mainly enabling people who are in different cities or around
the world to come together but in fact and what i was trying to convey in this picture there's a lot of
very local uses of video the proverbial looking at something while i'm shopping
with and getting an opinion from somebody else to make sure i'm getting the right thing or very
